summary: Coronaviruses belong to the order Nidovirales, family Coronaviridae, and subfamily Coronavirinae. the subfamily includes four genera: Alphacoronavirus, Betacoronavirus, Gammacoronavirus, and the more recently discovered Deltacoronavirus. in humans, coronaviruses are typically responsible for upper respiratory infections and are the second leading cause of the common cold. plasma were found to be PCR positive for the virus, indicating that viruses may be transmitted through feed [14,15] with high concentrations of PEDV excreted in feces of infected pigs, only 1 gram of infected feces is necessary to contaminate over 450,000 kilograms of feed. the results from these studies suggest that virus contamination likely occurs post-processing in order to cause an active infection in pigs. the NVSL strain of PDCoV and Purdue strain of TGEV was propagated in vero-81 (African green monkey kidney, ATCC, CCL-81TM) cells were grown in minimum essential medium (MEM) with Earle’s salts. the inoculated cells were observed for the appearance of virus-induced cytopathic effects (CPE) the cells were subjected to three freeze-thaw cycles (-80°C/25°C) and centrifugation at 2500 g for 15 min at 4°C. the supernatant was collected and aliquoted into 50 mL centrifuge tubes. the pH of the suspension was then measured using a pH probe. the value was recorded. the pH was measured in triplicate, while chemical composition values were determined from a single measurement. one mL of either PEDV, PDCoV, or TGEV was added to the appropriate vials and mixed thoroughly. only one virus was added to each ingredient sample to prevent interactions between viruses in a single ingredient sample. all samples were stored at room temperature (approximately 25°C) titer plates were incubated at 37°C under 5% CO2 until CPE appeared. the highest dilution showing CPE was considered the end point. weibull distribution model was used to describe inactivation patterns. an ANOVA test using the mixed procedure of SAS (SAS Inst., Cary, NC) was used to compare differences between treatment means. the fixed effect was the feed ingredient being analyzed. results for each virus were analyzed independently. maintenance medium for TGEV consisted of MEM with antibiotics and 4% donor horse serum (DHS, Hyclone) the cells were incubated at 37°C for 1 h for virus adsorption. the inoculated cells were observed for the appearance of virus-induced cytopathic effects (CPE) the pH of feed and feed ingredients was measured by mixing 50 mL of distilled water with 5g of sample. the mixture was stirred on a magnetic stirrer for 20 min to allow the feed to be suspended in the liquid. the pH of the suspension was then measured using a pH probe. five gram aliquots of complete feed and feed ingredients were prepared in scintillation vials. one mL of either PEDV, PDCoV, or TGEV with initial titers of 3.2 104, 1.5 106, 6.8 106, respectively, was added to the appropriate vials. supernatants were inoculated into vero-81and ST monolayers in 96-well microtiter plates. inoculated cells were incubated at 37°C under 5% CO2 until CPE appeared. highest dilution showing CPE was considered the end point. data by calculating adjusted R2 (Adj. R2) as follows: m is the number of observations, j is the number of model parameters, and SSQ is the sum of squares. a correlation analysis using the corr procedure of SAS (SAS Inst., Cary, NC) was done to determine potential associations between feed and feed ingredient chemical composition and the delta values for complete feed. was observed for TGEV, where soybean meal had a greater delta value (41.94 days) compared with that observed for the other ingredients. for all ingredients with an average titer of 3.2x104 for PEDV, 1.5x106 for PDCoV, and 6.8x106 for TGEV. a dose of 5.6 x 101 TCID50/mL, or 1.7 log TCID50/mL, of PEDV is necessary to cause an active infection in a feed matrix [17]. soybean meal also had the highest survival for both viruses with a virus concentration of 5.17 log TCID50/mL of PDCoV and 4.95 log TCID50/mL of TGEV even after 56 days of incubation. PDCoV (r = 0.4823, P 0.05) and TGEV (r = 0.4128, P 0.05). this means that as predicted, as moisture content increases, so does virus survival. however, the same relationship was not observed in PEDV survival. low virus titers may not represent the virus titers observed in the field. a study measuring the residual amount of PEDV in a contaminated feed bin estimated these CT values between 19.5 and 22.2. this amount of virus is equivalent to 8.9 to 9.2 log copies of RNA/g.
